title: Investor worth £1,200,000,000 who is helping Extinction Rebellion
text:
Sir Christopher Hohn has donated £50,000 to the group (Picture: PA/ Getty)

A British billionaire has revealed he has donated £50,000 towards Extinction Rebellion.

Investor Sir Christopher Hohn, who is worth a whopping £1,200,000,000, says he supports the group because there is an ‘urgent need’ to stop humanity from ‘destroying the world with climate change’.

The Children’s Investment Fund Foundation, a charity he co-founded in 2002, also donated more than £150,000, the Daily Telegraph reports.

However none of the money was spent on this week’s civil disobedience, the publication said.

More than 1,100 people have been arrested in London since the two-week protests began on Monday, October 7.

He is currently worth an estimated £1,200,000,000 (Picture: Getty Images)

Protests will be taking place across London for two weeks (Picture: PA)

They are barricading main roads (Picture: PA)

None of the money has gone on the protests, it was claimed (Picture: PA)

Yesterday London City Airport was hit by activists who attempted to block the entrance with a ‘Hong Kong-style occupation of the terminal building’.

Around 50 people were arrested, with many climbing the roof or gluing themselves to the entrance of the Docklands Light Railway (DLR) station serving the airport.

Partially-sighted former Paralympic cyclist, James Brown, was also pictured climbing on top of a British Airways plane to stand up ‘for everybody’s kids’.

Met Commissioner Dame Cressida Dick said the incident was a ‘reckless, stupid and dangerous thing’ to do but difficult for officers at the airport to ‘predict or stop from happening’.

She insisted Scotland Yard has enough cells to hold the activists, but warned that officers were being taken away from tackling knife crime or safeguarding children.

More than 1,100 people have been arrested (Picture: PA)

London City Airport was targeted yesterday (Picture: AFP)

Paralympic cyclist, James Brown climbed on top of a plane (Picture: Extinction Rebellion)

Met Commissioner Dame Cressida Dick called the protests ‘utterly irresponsible'(Picture: AFP)

She also said protesters were ‘utterly irresponsible and completely unreasonable’ for their determination to take over and occupy important arterial roads in London.

Urging them to demonstrate in the pedestrian area of Trafalgar Square, she added: ‘Protest lawfully or go home.’

Today activists have already begun protesting at the BBC Broadcasting House, asking why their children’s futures are not ‘front page news’.

Their plans include holding a ‘Cold War-style emergency broadcast’ outside the building, followed by a panel discussion involving members of XR Youth.

description: Billionaire investor Sir Christopher Hohn supports Extinction Rebellion to stop humanity from 'destroying the world with climate change'.
